attachments.text: For a while now, I've been thinking about how terms like "white privilege," "inclusion" and "unconscious bias" all sound just... too nice. Don't they see...

but I think figuring out what footing you can share is a step
That’s a good idea and generally a good way to converse with people. I guess I tend to react in a way that may make people defensive which doesn’t help the situation

<@U0K8ZSHN0> there’s this awesome speaker by the name of glenn singleton who does workshops on diversity. part of his workshop focuses on how to speak about diversity <http://www.pacificeducationalgroup.com/pages/about_team_executive_bios>
The Four Agreements of Courageous Conversations:

*1. Stay engaged:*  Staying engaged means “remaining morally, emotionally, intellectually, and socially involved in the dialogue”

*2. Experience discomfort:*  This norm acknowledges that discomfort is inevitable, especially, in dialogue about race, and that participants make a commitment to bring issues into the open.  It is not talking about these issues that create divisiveness.  The divisiveness already exists in the society and in our schools.  It is through dialogue, even when uncomfortable, the healing and change begin.

*3. Speak your truth:*  This means being open about thoughts and feelings and not just saying what you think others want to hear.

*4. Expect and accept nonclosure:*  This agreement asks participants to “hang out in uncertainty” and not rush to quick solutions, especially in relation to racial understanding, which requires ongoing dialogue.

text: It has an off putting name, but Nonviolent Communication is a FANTASTIC way of letting others feel heard/affirmed in their reality, while still showing your personal truths. I’m a HUGE fan of this method.
<@U0K8ZSHN0>: feel free to ask me about it, the book is def worth a read & Marshall has some amazing videos on Youtube.
thanks <@U1172PRDX> and <@U0J6TE0CA> !
I need this book in my life
we should order one for the office
It’s something everyone should read. Marshall Rosenberg used to go to Refugee camps & talk with opposing sides, here’s a short intro: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgaeHeIL39Y>
